docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors around the state plan to stop work on Feb. 3 to protest rising malpractice insurance costs. Elective surgery and other nonemergency procedures will have to wait that day. But Dr. Robert S. Rigolosi, president of the Medical Society of New Jersey, said in a statement last week that doctors would still deliver babies and continue urgent care, such as treatment for cancer. The medical society has not officially endorsed the job action, and it was not clear how many of the state's 24,000 doctors would take part. Physicians around the nation have long sought caps on financial awards in malpractice suits as higher insurance premiums continue to prompt doctors to leave or restrict their practices. Governor McGreevey said in a statement that a work stoppage was not the way to encourage legislators to act. George James
docs.abstract: Medical Society of New Jersey president Dr Robert Rigolosi says doctors around state will stage work stoppage on February 3 to protest rising malpractice insurance costs (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT was 19 degrees and the wind was whipping off Lake Erie as Ed Fire climbed onto the back of a pickup last Tuesday to address 150 workers who were on strike against General Electric. ''The greed of General Electric must stop,'' thundered Mr. Fire, president of G.E.'s largest union, as he denounced the company for increasing employee health care co-payments this month.

headline.main: Private Sector; Stirring Words, Realist Tactics

docs.lead_paragraph: IT was a strange but somehow fitting coincidence that two of Long Island's highest-ranking and longest-serving Republican politicians unexpectedly announced last week that they planned to leave office. The decisions of Richard V. Guardino Jr., the supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, and Robert J. Gaffney, the Suffolk county executive, were entirely separate and independent. But together, their announcements -- which were made within hours of each other last Monday -- upended the political apple carts of both counties and sent dozens of politicians of all stripes scattering to rethink their own political futures.

docs.lead_paragraph: I read Ann Patchett's superb essay with interest and a degree of hope (The Way We Live Now, Jan. 5). While I was gratified by her, and perhaps society's, continuing respect for doctors, I was struck by the disconnect between the article's portrayal and the plight of my beloved profession. Given debts of $100,000 or more incurred during school, years of low-salaried postgraduate training, outrageous increases in the cost of malpractice insurance and reimbursement rates that approximate 45 cents on the dollar (unthinkable for attorneys, accountants, plumbers and other skilled workers), the best and the brightest of the next generation are choosing careers other than medicine. The malpractice crisis in many states has caused surgeons to stop operating, obstetricians to stop delivering babies and trauma centers to close their doors. I hope that Senator Frist and Governor Dean will use their increased visibility and political skills to address the quandary of their former profession as well as the other important health-care issues Patchett mentioned. Melvin P. Weinstein, M.D. Princeton Junction, N.J.
docs.abstract: Letter from Dr Melvin P Weinstein on disconnect between Ann Patchett's Jan 5 article on respect for doctors and sorry plight of doctors today

docs.lead_paragraph: A flood of last-minute requests to the biggest program aiding small businesses and nonprofit groups in Lower Manhattan in the wake of the World Trade Center attack has pushed the amount of aid approved to more than the $481 million allotted for the program, according to the state agency that runs the program. Beyond that, 1,700 applications remain to be processed. Officials of the World Trade Center Business Recovery Grant Program say they have approved more than 13,000 applications for $492 million. Michael Marr, a spokesman for the agency, the Empire State Development Corporation, added that most of the 1,700 applications still pending flooded in on the last days before the program's filing deadline on Dec. 31.

headline.main: 9/11 Program Finally Gets Flood of Requests for Help

docs.lead_paragraph: The Wade Cook Financial Corporation was ordered liquidated by a federal bankruptcy judge yesterday after its chief executive failed to provide testimony requested by creditors. The company, which advertised itself widely on popular radio programs, provided training seminars for stock trading. Creditors asked the court last month to force the company and its subsidiary, Stock Market Institute of Learning Inc., into bankruptcy, saying that employees had not been paid back wages and that their health insurance was canceled after the company collected and pocketed premiums. A bankruptcy judge in Seattle ordered the company into Chapter 7 bankruptcy proceedings, which call for liquidation of the company's assets. Wade Cook, the chief executive and founder of the company, predicted that the company would earn $6 million in 2002. The company lost $6.2 million in the first nine months of the year, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline.main: JUDGE ORDERS LIQUIDATION OF WADE COOK FINANCIAL

docs.abstract: Judge orders Chapter 7 bankruptcy liquidation of stock-trading educator Wade Cook Financial Corp, which owes employees back wages and pocketed their health insurance premiums (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: With doctors across the country protesting the cost of malpractice insurance, President Bush is making a renewed push for strict limits on the jury awards he blames for skyrocketing premiums. Insurers have indeed been paying more in recent years to cover lawsuits and malpractice settlements.
docs.abstract: Pres Bush is making new push for strict limits on jury awards he blames for skyrocketing malpractice premiums, as doctors across country protest insurance costs; insurers are paying more in recent years to settle suits, but experts point to other factors, such as poor investment returns and insurers' own business practices; graphs; Bush plan is likely to sail through House but fight expected in Senate, even though new majority leader Dr Bill Frist will lead coalition of supporters (M)
docs.snippet: With doctors across the country protesting the cost of malpractice insurance, President Bush is making a renewed push for strict limits on the jury awards he blames for skyrocketing premiums.    Insurers have indeed been paying more in recent years...

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush called for a cap on medical malpractice awards yesterday as a way to control soaring premiums for medical liability insurance that have sparked protests from doctors in several states. But the president's plan seemed far too narrow to solve a multifaceted crisis, and the limit he suggested -- $250,000 for pain and suffering -- is too low. While changing some parts of the nation's tort system may be a good idea, it has to be part of larger, more fundamental reforms that will benefit -- and be fair to -- both doctors and patients. There is no doubt that malpractice premiums in some areas have escalated to unaffordable levels. Obstetricians in Miami paid up to $210,000 last year for liability insurance, while general surgeons were charged up to $174,000, according to The Medical Liability Monitor, an independent newsletter. Even where bills are lower, the charges have soared high enough to drive some doctors to retire, leave the state or give up high-risk procedures.
docs.abstract: Editorial on Pres Bush's call for cap on medical malpractice awards to control soaring premiums; says plan seems far too narrow to solve multifaceted crisis, and proposed limit of $250,000 for pain and suffering is too low; warns Republican lawmakers that in their haste to rescue doctors and spite Democratic-leaning trial lawyers they should not beleaguer patients who have suffered truly grievous harm
